ygData.subject: Re: New paper showing HyperNEAT produces best gait yet for a real robot

Nice work Jeff, I hadn't realized you were still improving on the robot r=
esults.  It is indeed good for the community to demonstrate top-notch real-=
world results.  It's also interesting that it learns a better real-world ga=
it when trained in simulation as opposed to in the real robot, which could =
be viewed as counterintuitive.  

Congrats on the publication!

ken

--- In=
 neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune  wrote:
>
> Hello everyone,
> 
> I am ver=
y pleased to announce a new paper that shows HyperNEAT evolving a
> nice ga=
it for a real (physical) robot. On the robot platform we tested on,
> Hyper=
NEAT outperformed nine other machine learning algorithms from three
> previ=
ous papers to produce the fasted gait yet recorded for this robot. I
> thin=
k this result is great for our community because it shows that
> HyperNEAT =
can perform great--and outperform traditional machine learning
> algorithms=
--on difficult, real-world engineering problems, instead of just
> in simul=
ation and on diagnostic/toy problems.
> 
> 
> The cite for the paper is:
> =

> Lee S, Yosinski J, Glette K, Lipson H, Clune J. 2013.
> 
> Evolving gait=
s for physical robots with the HyperNEAT generative encoding:
> the benefit=
s of simulation. Applications of Evolutionary Computing.
> Springer.
> 
> 
=
> You can see videos of the evolved gaits at the end of this video:
> 
> ht=
tp://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3DV2ADU8YWIug
> 
> 
> A pdf of the preprint of=
 the paper is here:
> 
> http://jeffclune.com/publications/2013-LeeEtal-Hyp=
erNEAT+Sim.pdf
> 
> 
> Please let me know if you have any questions.
> 
> 
=
> Best regards,
> 
> *Jeff Clune*
> 
> 
> Assistant Professor
> 
> Computer=
 Science
> 
> University of Wyoming
